head.supplied: 20/1/83 ¶ ¶ Yesterday, dear Prof Tate, I received back the paper of your Candidature at the R.S. of London, from the F.R.S., among in Australia it was circulated. ¶ It bears the signatures now of Dr...

div.p: Barr Smith Library, University of Adelaide, SA.

Yesterday, dear Prof Tate, I received back the paper of your Candidature at the R.S. of London, from the F.R.S., among in Australia it was circulated.
See M to R. Tate, 15 January 1883 (in this edition as 83-03-15b). It bears the signatures now of Dr Hector, Dr v. Haast, Prof M'Coy, Mr Ellery, and Sir G. Verdon from general knowledge, — and of course mine from personal knowledge.

As Judge Sir J. Cockle is still in England his Honor's signature has to be obtained at home, and then there would be wanting among Australian F's only that of Prof Liversidge, to whom I do not like to send the paper, as he is in intimate relation and cooperation with the Rev Jul. Ten. Woods at the R.S. of N.SW.; — and as it is best that the latter should not know directly there of your steps, as then a misconstruction could perhaps be put on my action in this matter.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;
font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;

div.p:
Be so good to write to Sir Joseph, which of your friends ought to be applied to in Britain & Ireland, to support your election I added to your qualifications that of a scientific traveller in Central America
Some years before moving to Australia, Tate had worked in 1867-8 in Central America and Venezuela, mostly on mining prospects.
